--- title: "Welcome Aboard üôå" title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: ./images/bg.png # data-background-size: stretch # data-slide-number: none format: live-revealjs: output-file: 01-syllabus-slides.html webr: cell-options: autorun: false # packages: # - tidyverse --- # {visibility="hidden"} \def\bx{\mathbf{x}} \def\bg{\mathbf{g}} \def\bw{\mathbf{w}} \def\bbeta{\boldsymbol \beta} \def\bX{\mathbf{X}} \def\by{\mathbf{y}} \def\bH{\mathbf{H}} \def\bI{\mathbf{I}} \def\bS{\mathbf{S}} \def\bW{\mathbf{W}} \def\T{\text{T}} \def\cov{\mathrm{Cov}} \def\cor{\mathrm{Corr}} \def\var{\mathrm{Var}} \def\E{\mathrm{E}} \def\bmu{\boldsymbol \mu} \DeclareMathOperator*{\argmin}{arg\,min} \def\Trace{\text{Trace}} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: # Taipei, Taiwan {background-image="images/01-syllabus/taiwan.jpeg" background-size="cover" background-position="50% 50%" background-color="#447099"} ::: {.absolute bottom="50" right="10"} ![](images/01-syllabus/taiwan.svg){width="500" fig-alt="Taiwan location"} ::: ::: notes - Hello everyone, how are you? I hope you have a great winter break. Welcome to 3570 Introduction to Data Science course. I am your instructor Cheng-Han Yu. - First thing first. Get to know each other. Let me first introduce my self. I was born and grew up in Taipei, Taiwan, my home country, which is a island right next to China. Taipei is a big city in terms of population. It is about the same population size as Chicago. This building is called Taipei 101, which is the tallest building in Taiwan. ::: ## My Journey {background-image="images/01-syllabus/sample_gate.png" background-size="cover" background-position="50% 50%" background-opacity="0.3"} - Assistant Professor (2020/08 - ) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/mu.svg){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: - Postdoctoral Fellow ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/rice.png){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: - PhD in Statistics ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/ucsc.png){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: - MA in Economics/PhD program in Statistics ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/iub.png){fig-align='center' width=20%} ::: ::: ::: notes After college, working and doing military service for several years, I came to the US for my PhD degree. Originally I would like to study economics, but then I switched my major to statistics. - I got my master degree in economics from Indiana University Bloomington, then I transferred to UC Santa Cruz to finish my PhD studies. - Then I spent two years doing my postdoctoral research at Rice University in Houston, Texas. - Finally, in fall 2020, I came to Marquette as an assistant professor. - Midwest/Indiana-West/California-South/Texas-Midwest/Wisconsin - Been to any one of these universities/cities? - The most beautiful campus. - Who are international students? I can totally understand how hard studying and living in another country. Feel free to share your stories or difficulties, and I am more than happy to help you if you have any questions. - Poor listening and speaking skills. I was shy. - OK so, this is my background. How about you introducing yourself as well. You can share anything, your major, hobbies, your favorite food, what do you want to do after graduation, anything, - I have the class list. I'd like to learn your face and remember your name. You know, you all wear a mask. It's hard to recognize you and connect your name and your face. - When I call your name, you can say something about yourself. No need to be long, couple of seconds are good. ::: ## How to Reach Me - Office hours **TuTh 3:20 - 4:20 PM** and **Wed 2 - 3 PM** in **Cudahy Hall 353**. - üìß [cheng-han.yu\@marquette.edu](mailto:cheng-han.yu@marquette.edu){.email} - Answer your question within 24 hours. - Expect a reply on **Monday** if shoot me a message **on weekends**. - Start your subject line with **\[math3570\]** or **\[cosc3570\]** followed by a **clear description of your question**. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/3570_email.png){fig-align='center' width=45%} ::: ::: - I will **NOT** reply your e-mail if ... **Check the email policy in the [syllabus](https://math3570-s26.github.io/website/course-syllabus.html)**! ## When You Have Two Dr. Yu in One Semester üòÇ {visibility="hidden"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/email_example_student.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/email_example.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: notes - This is a real case happened last semester. A student of my class sent her homework of another class linear systems to me because the instructor of that course also has last name Yu, and she messed up. So if you remember to add course number in the subject line, it will greatly reduce the possibility of sending a wrong message. And it will save your time and my time, and so we all can work more efficiently. Right? ::: ## What is This Course? - **Every** *aspect of doing a practical data science project, from importing data to deploying what we learn from data*. . . . ‚ùì **What are prerequisites?**\ üëâ COSC 1010 (Intro Programming) and MATH 4720 (Intro Stats) or MATH 2780 (Intro Regression)
. . . ‚ùì **Is this like another intro stats course?**\ üëâ No. Statistics and data science are closely related. . . . Nowadays\ üëâ Data science is a *broader* subject than statistics. . . . üëâ Statistics focuses more on *analyzing and learning from data*, a part of the entire workflow of data science.
. . . ‚ùì **Is this like another intro CS or programming course?**\ üëâ Absolutely not. We learn how to **code for doing data science**, not for understanding computer systems and structures. ::: notes - Of course we will not cover every detail form A to Z of DS in one semester becuase DS is such a huge subject, just like computer science. It's impossible to learn CS in one semester by just taking intro to CS, right? So we'll just learn the basic and essential concepts and tools used is DS. ::: ## What is NOT Covered in This Course - **Advanced data analytics and computing** - MATH 4750 Statistical Computing - MATH 4760 Time Series Analysis - MATH 4780 Regression Analysis - MATH 4790 Bayesian Statistics - COSC 4600 Fundamentals of Artificial Intelligence - COSC 4610 Data Mining - COEN 4860 Introduction to Neural Networks . . . - **Big data**: We start with small, in-memory data sets. You don't know how to tackle big data unless you have experience with small data. . . . - **Database**: Learn SQL in - COSC 4800 Principles of Database Systems - INSY 4052 Database Management Systems. ::: notes - We won't talk about topics like cloud computing, parallel computing, distributed computing. - **Big data techniques**: As a beginner, we focus on small, in-memory datasets. You can't tackle big data unless you have experience with small data. ::: ## What Computing Languages? ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} \~ 60% ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](./images/01-syllabus/Rlogo.png){fig-align='center' width=50%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} \~ 40% ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c3/Python-logo-notext.svg){fig-align='center' width=45%} ::: ::: ::: ::::: - You've learned Python in COSC 1010. Being R-Python bilingual is getting more important! . . . üëâ Wouldn't it be great to add both languages to your resume! üòé . . . ‚ùå Don't want to learn *R and/or Python*? Take another section or in *next* semester\~! ‚ùå Drop deadline: **01/20 (Tue), 11:59 PM**. ## Where to Code? [Posit Cloud](https://posit.cloud/) :::::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/03-posit/posit.png){fig-align='center' width=60%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"}
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/03-posit/rstudio-logo.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/38/Jupyter_logo.svg){fig-align='center' width=50%} ::: ::: ::: :::::: - Have nice computing power and interactive collaboration with me and your teammates! ## Course Materials - Course Website - ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} [![](./images/01-syllabus/website_s26.png){fig-align='center' width=100%}](https://math3570-s26.github.io/website/) ::: ::: ## Textbook (Really?!) ::: r-stack ![](./images/01-syllabus/read1.png){.fragment width="1800" height="1000"} ![](./images/01-syllabus/read2.png){.fragment width="1600" height="900"} ![](./images/01-syllabus/read3.png){.fragment width="1400" height="400"} ![](./images/01-syllabus/read4.png){.fragment width="1200" height="800"} ::: ## :::::: columns ::: {.column width="30%"} [*Python for Data Analysis, 3E*](https://wesmckinney.com/book/) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} [![](./images/01-syllabus/py4ds_book.jpg){fig-align='center' width=100%}](https://wesmckinney.com/book/) ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [*R for Data Science 2nd edition*](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} [![](./images/01-syllabus/r4ds_book2.jpeg){fig-align='center' width=100%}](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/) ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} [*Tidy Modeling with R*](https://www.tmwr.org/) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} [![](./images/01-syllabus/tmwr_book.png){fig-align='center' width=100%}](https://www.tmwr.org/) ::: ::: ::: :::::: ## Learning Management System ([D2L](https://d2l.mu.edu/d2l/home/630428)) ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} [![](./images/01-syllabus/d2l_s26.png){fig-align='center' width=100%}](https://d2l.mu.edu/d2l/home/630428) ::: ::: - **Assessments \> Grades** ## Grading Policy ‚ú® - Your grade is from the following categories and distribution - **25%** In-class lab activities - **10%** In-class AI activities - **45%** Mini projects - **20%** Final project competition - ‚ùå You must participate in the final presentation in order to pass the course. - ‚ùå You will **NOT** be allowed to do any extra credit projects/homework/exam to compensate for a poor grade. ## Grade-Percentage Conversion - $[x, y)$ means greater than or equal to $x$ and less than $y$. For example, 94.0 is in \[94, 100\] and the grade is A and 93.8 is in \[90, 94) and the grade is A-. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Grade Percentage
A [94, 100]
A- [90, 94)
B+ [87, 90)
B [84, 87)
B- [80, 84)
C+ [77, 80)
C [74, 77)
C- [70, 74)
D+ [65, 70)
D [60, 65)
F [0, 60)
````` ::: ::: ## Lab Exercises (25%) - Graded as **Complete/Incomplete** and used as evidence of attendance and participation. - Allowed to have **one** incomplete lab exercise without any penalty. - Beyond that, **2%** grade percentage will be taken off for each missing/incomplete exercise. - You will create a project in [Posit Cloud](https://posit.cloud) saving all of your lab exercises. (We'll go through know-how together) ## AI activities (10%) - AI activities are short presentations during class. They are usually graded as **complete or incomplete**. - AI activities are used as evidence of both attendance and participation. - Groups take turn to present what they learn from GenAI about data science. ## Mini Projects (45%) - You will work in a team on **3** mini projects. - This project will focus on a subset of the course content up to that point, for example data wrangling and visualization or a simple predictive model. - More detailed instructions and rubric will be provided later in the semester. ## Final Project Competition (20%) - You will be team up to do the final project. - Your project can be in either of the following categories: 1. **Data analysis** using statistical models or machine learning algorithms 2. Introduce a **R or Python package** not learned in class, including **live demo** 3. Introduce a **data science tool (visualization, computing, etc)** not learned in class, including **live demo** 4. Introduce a **programming language** not learned in class for doing data science, including **live demo**, Julia, SQL, MATLAB, SAS for example. 5. **Web development**: Shiny website or dashboard, including **live demo** - The final project presentation is on **Monday, 5/4, 10:30 AM - 12:30 PM**. - More information will be released later. ## Document Generative AI Use ::::: columns ::: {.column width="80%"} - You may use generative AI tools such as ChatGPT and Gemini to generate a first draft of text for your work, provided that this use is **documented and cited**. - Unless explicitly stated otherwise, you may make use of any online resources, but you must **explicitly cite/document** where you obtained any code you directly use or use as inspiration in your solutions. ::: ::: {.column width="20%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/01-syllabus/genai.png){fig-align='center' width=80%} ::: ::: ::: ::::: - If you use GenAI, please include the followings in your submitted work: - **Why/How I used AI (prompts or questions)** - **Generated output (screenshot or copy-paste excerpt)** - **How I used the output** ## Document Generative AI Use :::::: columns :::: {.column width="50%"} - **Why/How I used AI (prompts and questions)** - *I asked ChatGPT to generate a histogram using R.* - **Generated output (screenshot or copy-paste excerpt)** ::: tiny ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/01-syllabus/genai_screenshot.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: :::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - **How I used the output** - *I reviewed the suggestions, but I did not use the exact code. Instead, I change the code format and breaks value to 50.* ::: :::::: ## GenAI and Academic Integrity ```{=html}
``` . . .

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
